results.title: Gallery of the great. No. 1. Churchill
results.brief_description: Profile of Winston Spencer Churchill, from his days in the Spanish forces in Cuba; through to war correspondent; Home Secretary; Mayor during the 1914-18 war; Chancellor of the Ex-Checker; and finally a victorious Prime Minister at the end of WWII. Contains archival footage.

results.title: Gala
results.creator_credit: John Smith, Michael McKennirey, Canada Council and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: For the first time in Canadian dance history, eight of the country’s leading dance companies gathered to perform on a single stage. The time, May 1981. The place, the National Arts Centre in Ottawa. The event, billed as the Canadian Dance Spectacular, offered a rich program of classical and jazz ballet, modern dance, gymnastics, pantomime and theatre. As well as recording this outstanding performance, Gala went backstage to capture the pre-performance jitters and post-performance elation. A film that showcases Canada’s cultural heritage. Film without words.

results.title: Gabriel Gate Cooks for Everybody
results.brief_description: This video brings together all of Gabriel Gate’s “Good Food” segments from the ABC TV’s “Everybody” program. In each segment, he examines one particular food group, and provides some tasty and healthy recipes using those ingredients.

results.title: Future urban form
results.brief_description: “Summary: attemps to describe, analyse and evaluate certain trends and future possibilities for urban form in britain. two trends are isolated upward extension outward growth. the processes that underlie these trends are the examined. the development of the lift being largely responsible for upward extension, while outward growth is largely associated with the railroad and car. the ideas of a number of visionaries are then examined”

results.title: Future eaters. Ep. 3: eating the future
results.creator_credit: Ian Cuming, Richard Keefe, ABC-TV (Australia), North South Productions and Television New Zealand. New Zealand Natural History Unit
results.brief_description: Episode three of a provocative three part ecological history of Australasia based on Dr Tim Flannery’s best selling book of the same name. It focuses on the exploitation for food of flora and fauna resources, firstly by the indigenous populations of Australia and New Zealand and then by European colonists. This episode looks at the introduction of European farming methods and feral creatures by colonists and their catastrophic effect on our local eco systems in the form of the extinction of many native fauna and irreversible damage to much of Australia’s land. Written and presented by Dr Tim Flannery. Further information available at www.abc.net.au/science/future.

results.title: Future eaters. Ep. 2: nomads of the wind
results.creator_credit: Ian Cuming, Richard Keefe, ABC-TV (Australia), North South Productions and Television New Zealand. New Zealand Natural History Unit
results.brief_description: Episode two of a provocative three part ecological history of Australasia based on Dr Tim Flannery’s best selling book of the same name. It focuses on the exploitation for food of flora and fauna resources, firstly by the indigenous populations of Australia and New Zealand and then by European colonists. This episode looks at the impact of hunting and fishing by Maori before European colonisation. The primeval forests of New Zealand were home to many unique creatures which they devoured to extinction. They also rapidly depleted marine life until they no longer had enough to eat. The result was war over resources, followed by conservation measures to preserve food sources, some of which continue to this day. Written and presented by Dr Tim Flannery. Further information available at www.abc.net.au/science/future.

results.title: Funny things happen down under
results.creator_credit: Joe McCormick, Roger Mirams and Pacific Films
results.brief_description: When the clubhouse of a group of country kids, known as the “Terrible ten” needs money for funding they invent numerous ways to make money. During their attempts at making puddings and selling mineral water they stumble on a formula for breeding coloured sheep.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joe McCormick, Roger Mirams and Pacific Films

results.title: Funny by George
results.creator_credit: Don Percy, Jeremy Kewley and Onkus Pictures
results.brief_description: A documentary about the life of one of Australia’s most famous and influential comedians. Wallace was a creative force as a writer of his own material for vaudeville sketches and feature films and as a painter, musician, dancer and composer. From his early beginnings in country travelling shows and vaudeville, he became Australia’s first genuine box office star of the sound era appearing in five feature films and achieving international success. Using rare photographs, home movies, feature film footage and contemporary interviews, the filmmakers explore his personal and professional life and examine his lasting influence, thus restoring Wallace to his rightful place as a key figure in Australian entertainment history. Narrated by Bill Kerr.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Percy, Jeremy Kewley and Onkus Pictures

results.title: Fungi
results.creator_credit: John Walker, William M. Harlow and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Defines fungi as simple plants dependent upon other organism for food. Illustrates how fungi grow and obtain their food. Explains their importance as a source of good, as agents in food processing and as a cause for disease in plants and animals.
